summary: Internal FBI email chain from April 2020 regarding a media inquiry from MailOnline UK about whether the FBI had sent a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request to the UK to question Prince Andrew as part of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The FBI confirms no comment but internally notes an MLAT was sent in early April.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: British royal who is the subject of an FBI Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request to the UK government as part of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and convicted sex offender; the inquiry referenced is the investigation into his activities.

persons.name: Kirsty Hayes
persons.context: Director in the UK Home Office to whom the FBI's MLAT request regarding Prince Andrew was reportedly sent.

persons.name: Vivek Chaudhary
persons.context: Reporter from MailOnline UK who sent the original media inquiry to the FBI National Press Office.

connections.description: Prince Andrew is the subject of an FBI MLAT request as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's activities.
The FBI sent a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request to the UK government seeking to question Prince Andrew.

events.title: FBI sends MLAT request to UK regarding Prince Andrew
events.description: The FBI sent a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request to the United Kingdom in early April 2020, seeking information from Prince Andrew as part of the Epstein investigation.

events.title: MailOnline inquiry to FBI about Prince Andrew
events.description: Reporter Vivek Chaudhary from MailOnline UK contacts the FBI National Press Office to inquire about a reported MLAT request sent to the UK to question Prince Andrew.

keyFacts: The FBI confirms internally that a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request was sent to the United Kingdom in early April 2020 regarding Prince Andrew and the Epstein investigation.
The MLAT request was reportedly sent to Kirsty Hayes, a director in the UK Home Office.
The FBI's standard public response to media inquiries on this matter was 'no comment'.
This document shows the FBI was actively seeking to question Prince Andrew as part of the Epstein investigation as of April 2020.
